Problem:
Consider a linear transformation of a vector space given by the matrix \\( P \\) which projects vectors onto a subspace. We explore the effects of applying another linear transformation \\( Q \\), which is a rotation matrix, on this vector space.

If a vector \\( v \\) is first projected via \\( P \\) and then rotated by \\( Q \\) at time t = 0, without further transformations, will the resultant vector at time T be the same as applying \\( Q \\) to \\( v \\) at t = 0 and then projecting?
Explanation: Projection and rotation generally do not commute. The operation order alters the resultant vector since \\( PQ(v) \\) is not the same as \\( QP(v) \\). The first operation projects then rotates, whereas the second rotates then projects, leading to different final vectors.
